choices.text: 24-hour pH recording
Esophageal manometry

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented to the physician with complaints of heartburn and a sour taste in the mouth for the past 1 year. The physician prescribed him proton pump inhibitors, but the symptoms did not improve. What is the immediate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopy

 

Option A:

 

  • The immediate next step in the management of the patient with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) who does not respond to treatment is to perform endoscopy. This allows the surgeon to assess the signs of acid reflux such as esophagitis and its complications like hiatus hernia.
  • If the endoscopy shows normal findings, then the presence of acid reflux can be confirmed by 24-hour pH recording. This method is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of GERD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. 24-hour pH recording - This is a diagnostic test used to confirm GERD by measuring the frequency and duration of acid reflux episodes. It's typically considered when the diagnosis of GERD is uncertain or to evaluate the effectiveness of acid-suppression therapy or prior to surgery for GERD.

 

Option C. Esophageal manometry - This test measures the function of the lower esophageal sphincter and the esophageal muscles. It's generally used in the workup of patients with suspected motility disorders.

 

Option D. Fundoplication - This is a surgical procedure used to treat GERD. It is considered when medical therapy fails and the diagnosis of GERD is confirmed, but it is not a diagnostic step and is not appropriate as an immediate next step without further evaluation.

 

Given these options, the most appropriate immediate next step in the management of this patient is A. Endoscopy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In patients with reflux symptoms not responding to PPI, the diagnosis is confirmed by first performing an endoscopy.
  • 24-hour pH recording of GERD- gold standard investigation:

 

In this procedure, a pH probe is placed 5 cm above the upper end of the lower esophageal sphincter for 24 hours.

 

  • Reflux is defined as a drop of pH below 4 for more than 4% time in a 24-hour period or DeMeester scoring of 14.7 or higher.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th edition Pg 1114

choices.text: Barrett’s esophagus
Schatzki ring
Eosinophilic esophagitis

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female patient came to the physician with complaints of heartburn and regurgitation of food. The symptoms have been present for 3 years but have worsened for the past 3 months. She took over the counter medications, but the symptoms did not subside. Upper GI endoscopy shows the following presentation:

 

 

What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barrett’s esophagus

 

Option A:

 

The following image is an upper GI endoscopic image of Barrett's esophagus. It shows tongue shaped projections in the surrounding mucosa.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Schatzki Ring – A Schatzki ring is a narrowing of the lower esophagus that can cause difficulty swallowing (dysphagia). It typically appears as a thin ring on endoscopy and wouldn't show the patchy red mucosa that is indicative of Barrett’s esophagus. The symptoms of heartburn and regurgitation are less specific to a Schatzki ring unless there is accompanying esophagitis.

 

Option C. Eosinophilic Esophagitis – This is an allergic/immune condition that results in a buildup of eosinophils in the esophagus, leading to esophageal dysfunction. On endoscopy, it can show multiple rings, white specks of eosinophilic infiltrates, and longitudinal furrows, none of which are visible in the provided image.

 

Option D. Pseudo-Achalasia – This refers to symptoms of achalasia due to carcinoma of esophagus. It would not cause the visible changes seen in Barrett’s esophagus on endoscopy.

 

Educational objective:

 

Barrett’s esophagus is the columnar metaplasia of lower esophagus.

 

Etiology/risk factors:

 

  • Chronic (>5 years) GERD symptoms,
  • Advanced age (>50 years),
  • Smoking, central obesity
  • Male gender.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • The vast majority of patients with Barrett’s esophagus in the community are asymptomatic

 

Diagnosis:

 

Through upper GI endoscopy with biopsy or chromoendoscopy. Biopsy shows the presence of columnar epithelium with mucus-secreting goblet cells (intestinal metaplasia). This is an important risk factor for adenocarcinoma of the esophagus.

 

Treatment:

 

  • When Barrett’s esophagus is discovered, the treatment is that of the underlying GERD.
  • Radio frequency ablation of mucosa
  • High grade dysplastic cases: esophagectomy

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th ed: page 1120

choices.text: Barrett’s esophagus

questions.text: Choose the odd one out with respect to risk factors of squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barrett’s esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

Barrett’s esophagus is the columnar metaplasia of lower esophagus. It is a risk factor for adenocarcinoma.

 

Educational objective:

 

Most common type of esophageal carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma

 

Risk factors for SCC:

 

  • Spirits: alcohol
  • Spices
  • Sepsis: HPV
  • Smoking
  • Plummer Vinson syndrome
  • Achalasia

 

Risk factors for adenocarcinoma:

 

  • Barrett's esophagus
  • GERD
  • Smoking
  • Obesity

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed pg 1136

choices.text: Sliding hiatus hernia predisposes to GERD
Heartburn and regurgitation are typical GERD symptoms
Regurgitation in GERD is well controlled by PPI’s
Extraesophageal symptoms may include chronic cough, laryngitis, asthma and dental erosions

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement with respect to GERD?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Regurgitation in GERD is well controlled by PPI’s

 

Option C:

 

Regurgitation in patients with GERD is a feature of advanced disease. Surgery of GERD, which are Anti-reflux procedures are needed to control the regurgitation symptoms of GERD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hiatus hernia is associated with GERD; it is formed when the weakened phreno-esophageal ligament and widened crural opening allow the proximal stomach to herniate through the diaphragmatic hiatus. Ageing, connective tissue disease and elevated intra-abdominal pressure (e.g., central obesity, pregnancy, tight garments, chronic straining) will further aggravate the hernia. An acid pocket is an area of unbuffered gastric acid that accumulates in the proximal stomach after meals and serves as a reservoir for acid reflux. Together with a hiatus hernia, it can exacerbate the severity and symptoms of GERD.

 

Option B:  Classical triad of GERD includes:

 

  • Heartburn
  • Regurgitation
  • Epigastric pain

 

Symptoms are often provoked by food, particularly after a full meal with increased intragastric pressure or food that delays gastric emptying (e.g., oily, spicy food). The reflux can cause an unpleasant taste, often described as ‘acidic’ or ‘bitter’.

 

Option D: Extraesophageal symptoms may include chronic cough, laryngitis, asthma and dental erosions (especially on the lingual and palatal tooth surfaces). Other conditions with proposed association with GERD include sinusitis, pulmonary fibrosis, pharyngitis and recurrent otitis media.

 

Educational objective:

 

Regurgitation in patients with GERD is a feature of advanced disease. While most patients’ symptoms are satisfactorily controlled with PPIs and other medications, surgery remains an important option.

 

The indications for surgery include:

 

  1. Incomplete symptom control with medical management,
  2. Intolerance of, or unwillingness to comply with, long-term medical therapy,
  3. Regurgitation despite medication (less well amenable to PPI),
  4. Presence of a large hiatus hernia,
  5. Complications arising from GORD, and (vi) extra-esophageal symptoms.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1111 to 1116

questions.text: Identify the anti-reflux procedure in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Floppy Nissen fundoplication

 

Explanation:

 

The shown image is of 360-degree fundal wrap also called as floppy Nissen fundoplication.

 

  • Toupet: Posterior 270° wrap

  • Dor: Anterior 180° wrap

  • Allison’s: Only crura is repaired, no fundal wrap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mechanism of fundoplication is to create a ‘floppy’ 360 degree wrap around the Gastro-esophageal junction and to restore the angle of His. It has the effect of increasing lower esophageal sphincter (LES) basal pressure, lessening transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxation (TLOSR) and reducing the capacity of the gastric fundus, thereby enhancing gastric emptying.

  • Complete fundoplication (Nissen) is associated with a higher incidence of short-term dysphagia but is most durable in reflux control.

  • The most common side effect of fundoplication is short- term dysphagia, related presumably to tissue oedema and inflammation. It usually resolves within 3 months of surgery.

  • Some patients may experience ‘gas-bloat syndrome’, especially after a complete fundoplication. Typically, the patient would complain of gaseous distension of the abdomen and failure to belch or vomit, together with an increase in flatulence.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th edition Pg 1116

questions.text: A patient on screening endoscopy is found to have the below finding incidentally in the middle esophagus. What does the below picture depict?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leiomyoma

 

Explanation:

 

  • Leiomyomas are the most common solid benign tumours of the esophagus. They are mostly found incidentally as a submucosal mass on endoscopy as seen in the image, but may produce compressive symptoms when large.

  • EUS shows a hypoechoic mass arising from the muscularis propria or the submucosal layer. They rarely become malignant; however, resection is indicated if enlarging on serial assessment.

  • Small leiomyomas can be enucleated with a thoracoscopic approach, keeping the mucosa intact. Pre-operative biopsy or EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is relatively contraindicated as the consequent scarring will increase the chance of breaching the mucosa during enucleation.

  • Endoscopic resection is possible using submucosal tunnelling endoscopic resection (STER); this creates a mucosal opening a short distance from the leiomyoma (3–5 cm proximally), allowing a submucosal tunnel to reach the lesion.

Other options:

A: Achalasia: Endoscopy will show narrowing in distal esophagus. Patients present with dysphagia

B. Varices: Endoscopy shows venous dilations in a case of portal hypertension with history of hematemesis.

 

D: Zenker’s diverticulum: This will be seen as an outpouching of the mucosa above the cricopharynx. The patient will present with regurgitation and halitosis. Endoscopy will show two lumens- one normal esophageal (blue arrow) and the other of the diverticulum (green arrow).

Educational Objective:

 

Leiomyomas are the most common solid benign tumours of the esophagus.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1134.

choices.text: Flexible endoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis
The barium swallow shows shouldering with rat tail appearance
EUS is the investigation of choice (IOC) to assess tumour invasion
T2 tumour is restricted to submucosa

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male patient presented with progressive dysphagia to solid foods more than liquid foods and significant weight loss. Barium swallow shows the following:

 

 

Choose the incorrect statement with respect to the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T2 tumour is restricted to submucosa

 

Option D:

 

  • The above barium swallow shows long segment narrowing, abrupt tapering and rat tail appearance of esophagus suggestive of esophageal carcinoma.
  • T2 is restricted to the muscularis layer. T1 is limited to mucosa and submucosa.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This is correct. Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis.

 

Option B. This is correct. Barium shows long segment narrowing, abrupt tapering and rat tail appearance of esophagus suggestive of esophageal carcinoma.

 

Option C. This is correct. Depth of invasion is best assessed by Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS).

 

Educational objective:

 

While endoscopy with biopsy is used for diagnosis, EUS is for local staging. T2 is tumor invading muscularis.

 

  • Esophageal carcinoma is a gastrointestinal tumour with poor prognosis due to late presentation.

 

Etiology & Risk factors for SCC:

 

  • Spirits: alcohol
  • Spices
  • Sepsis: HPV
  • Smoking
  • Plummer Vinson syndrome

 

Risk factors for adenocarcinoma:

 

  • Barrett's esophagus
  • GERD
  • Smoking
  • Obesity

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Progressive dysphagia is the most common symptom. Early symptoms may include a mild hold-up sensation that, if ignored, will progress from dysphagia to a solid, soft and eventually to a liquid diet.
  • There may often be anorexia, weight loss, odynophagia and regurgitation symptoms. Hoarseness may indicate involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve of any side.
  • Early cancers are usually asymptomatic and are only picked up on endoscopy performed for other reasons.

 

TNM classification of oesophageal cancer

 

 

Diagnosis: Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1136-38

choices.text: Virtual endoscopy
Narrow band imaging

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality in the picture shown?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Narrow band imaging

 

Option C:

 

  • “High-definition white light endoscopy including Narrow band imaging (blue light) is used to assess the mucosal and vascular patterns of the Barrett’s segment. NBI light consists of only two wavelengths: 415-nm blue light and 540-nm green light. The differential absorption and reflection of these spectra facilitates detection of mucosal abnormalities

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Additional chromoendoscopy using different agents, e.g., methylene blue, acetic acid or indigo carmine, could aid diagnosis.”

 

  • For squamous cell dysplasia and cancer, chromoendoscopy using Lugol’s iodine is a useful adjunct; the normal squamous mucosa will be stained brown, while dysplastic and early cancer remains unstained.

 

 

Chromoendoscopy with Lugol’s iodine spray

 

Option B: Virtual endoscopy

 

It is a CT scan with reconstruction of GI organ.

 

 

Option D: ICG imaging: Indocyanine green is injected and using fluorescence, the anatomy or the vascularity of the organ is assessed.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

While NBI is used for assessing submucosal vascularity in Barretts, Chromoendoscopy with spraying of Lugols iodine or Methylene blue will demarcate suspicious areas of tumor on endoscopy.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1120.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese patient undergoes a regular endoscopy during his check-up. The surgeon notices this endoscopic finding. What condition is he suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sliding hiatus hernia

 

Option B:

 

The given picture depicts a sliding hiatus hernia.

 

Hiatus hernia is a condition in which the abdominal contents migrate through the hiatal opening of the diaphragm into the mediastinum.

 

There are four types of hiatus hernia:

 

  1. The sliding hernia (type I) - accounting for most hiatus hernias where the OGJ is herniated upwards.

  2. The true para-esophageal/rolling hernia (type II) - where there is asymmetrical herniation of the stomach next to the esophagus and the OGJ remains in its normal intra-abdominal position.

  3. The more common mixed sliding and para-esophageal hernia (type III)

  4. When abdominal viscera other than the stomach migrates into the hernia sac, it is classified as type IV.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Esophageal carcinoma: This would appear as a mass arising from mucosa

 

Option D. Diaphragmatic paralysis: This would appear as an area of raised hemidiaphragm, best seen on CECT.

 

Educational objective:

 

A sliding hiatus hernia predisposes to GERD and is usually diagnosed in the presence of reflux symptoms. For asymptomatic patients, it can be an incidental finding on plain chest radiographs or CT as an intrathoracic gas bubble or fluid level.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1117

choices.text: The sliding hiatus hernia is the most common type
Increased age is a predisposing factor for hiatus hernia
Type 2 hiatus hernia mainly presents with obstruction symptoms
Sliding hiatus hernia is always symptomatic

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hiatus hernia is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sliding hiatus hernia is always symptomatic.

 

Option D:

 

A sliding hiatus hernia predisposes to GERD and is usually diagnosed in the presence of reflux symptoms. For asymptomatic patients, it can be an incidental finding on plain chest radiographs or CT as an intrathoracic gas bubble or fluid level. Thus, option D is incorrect.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The sliding hernia (type I) - accounting for most hiatus hernias where the OGJ is herniated upwards.

 

Option B. Increasing age is a risk factor is also true.

 

Option C. Type 2 or paraesophageal rolling type presents with obstructive symptoms due to risk of gastric volvulus.

 

Educational objective:

 

While sliding type of hiatus hernia is common, rolling type presents with obstructive symptoms. However, not every hiatus hernia is symptomatic, as some are found incidentally on endoscopy or imaging.

 

A hiatus hernia is a condition in which the abdominal contents migrate through the hiatal opening of the diaphragm into the mediastinum.

 

There are four types of hiatus hernia:

 

  1. The sliding hernia (type I) - accounting for most hiatus hernias where the OGJ is herniated upwards.
  2. The true para-esophageal/rolling hernia (type II) - where there is asymmetrical herniation of the stomach next to the esophagus and the OGJ remains in its normal intra-abdominal position.
  3. The more common mixed sliding and para-esophageal hernia (type III)
  4. When abdominal viscera other than the stomach migrates into the hernia sac, it is classified as type IV.

 

Hiatus hernia is closely related to advanced age and obesity. It may be missed on endoscopy, hence CT with oral contrast is the confirmatory test.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1117

questions.text: Annual risk of adenocarcinoma in Barrett’s esophagus without dysplasia is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.2 to 0.5%

 

Explanation:

 

  • For non-dysplastic Barrett’s, the risk of progression to cancer is around 0.2–0.5% per year.

  • This increases to around 0.7% per year for low-grade dysplasia.

  • For high-grade dysplasia, the risk of cancer progression can be as high as 7%.

  • The Seattle biopsy protocol, which includes four-quadrant random biopsies every 2 cm in addition to targeted biopsies on macroscopically visible lesions, is recommended at the time of diagnosis and subsequent surveillance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Annual risk of adenocarcinoma in Barrett’s esophagus without dysplasia is 0.2 to 0.5%.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1120

choices.text: Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) of Barrett's + PPI + Surveillance (6 monthly)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with history of smoking undergoes upper GI endoscopy for recurrent heart-burn. On evaluation, pinkish patches are seen extending from Z line upwards. Biopsy reveals mucous secreting goblet cells with low grade dysplasia. What will be the management of this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) of Barrett's + PPI + Surveillance

 

Option C: RFA of Barrett's + PPI + Surveillance (6 monthly)


Radiofrequency ablation (RFA), along with PPI therapy, is an effective treatment for Barrett’s esophagus with dysplasia. RFA aims to remove the dysplastic tissue, and PPIs are used to control acid reflux and promote healing with normal squamous epithelium.

 

  • The given scenario is suggestive of Barrett’s esophagus with low grade dysplasia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Surveillance. Surveillance alone may be considered for patients with non-dysplastic Barrett’s esophagus, but for those with confirmed low-grade dysplasia, surveillance typically requires the addition of medication and removal of dysplastic epithelium due to the increased risk of progression to high-grade dysplasia or adenocarcinoma.

 

Option B: Surveillance (3 to 5 yearly) + PPI. Combining surveillance with proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy is a common approach for managing Barrett’s esophagus without dysplasia. PPIs help control acid reflux, which can decrease the inflammatory stimulus for further dysplastic changes.

 

Option D: Floppy Nissen fundoplication. Anti-reflux surgery, such as a floppy Nissen fundoplication, is typically reserved for patients with GERD symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy and is not the standard initial treatment for Barrett’s esophagus with low-grade dysplasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of Barrett’s esophagus with low-grade dysplasia commonly includes surveillance and PPI therapy to control acid reflux, with radiofrequency ablation being an option for eradicating dysplastic tissue.

 

  • When Barrett’s esophagus without dysplasia is discovered, the treatment is that of the underlying GERD. Pharmacological therapy generally is the same as treatment of symptomatic GERD patients. Anti-reflux surgery is indicated if it is associated with GERD symptoms not responding to medical management.

  • In patients with dysplastic Barrett’s esophagus without suspicion of invasive cancer, the epithelium can be ablated or resected. Ablative therapy aims to completely eradicate all intestinal metaplasia. When mucosa regenerates after ablation in a non-acidic environment (when a high-dose PPI is prescribed), a ‘neo squamous’ lining is formed. Ablative approaches that are supported by evidence include photodynamic therapy, RFA and cryotherapy. Among these methods, RFA is most preferred.

  • In patients with high-grade dysplastic Barrett’s esophagus, ablative, endoscopic resection and esophagectomy should be considered.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed., Pg 1120-21.

choices.text: POEM with long myotomy
Heller’s Cardiomyotomy
Endoscopic dilation

questions.text: Preferred treatment for Type 3 Achalasia on High Resolution Manometry (HRM) is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) POEM with long myotomy

 

Option A:


Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM) is particularly beneficial for Type 3 Achalasia, which is characterized by spastic contractions of the distal esophagus. POEM allows for a tailored myotomy that can extend proximally beyond the limits of a standard Heller's myotomy, addressing the spastic segment more effectively.

 

Let's evaluate the treatment options for Type 3 Achalasia as indicated by High Resolution Manometry (HRM):

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Heller’s Cardiomyotomy. Heller's myotomy is a surgical procedure that cuts the muscles at the lower end of the esophagus and the top of the stomach to relieve dysphagia. While effective for Type 1 and Type 2 Achalasia, it may be less effective for Type 3 due to the spastic component of the disease.

 

Option C: Endoscopic dilation. Endoscopic dilation or pneumatic dilation is less effective for Type 3 Achalasia because it does not address the spastic contractions adequately.

 

Option D: CCB. Calcium Channel Blockers (CCB) can be used to reduce contractions in the esophagus; however, they are generally considered a palliative treatment and are not the primary treatment for any type of Achalasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For Type 3 Achalasia, which includes a spastic component of the esophagus, POEM with long myotomy is the preferred treatment as it can be customized to extend the myotomy length based on HRM and barium swallow findings, providing relief from dysphagia effectively.

 

  • Laparoscopic Heller’s myotomy is superior to single pneumatic dilatation in efficacy and durability. The surgical outcome is better in types I and II achalasia than in type III. For the latter, a longer extended proximal myotomy is often needed for adequate treatment.
  • In type III achalasia, there is a spastic component at the distal esophagus that responds less well to pneumatic dilatation and Heller’s myotomy. POEM has the advantage in that it can extend the length of the myotomy proximally, tailored to preoperative HRM and barium swallow parameters.

 

POEM can also be utilized to treat other types of ‘spastic’ esophageal motility disorders such as distal esophageal spasm and hypercontractile esophagus.

 

  • However, without any anti-reflux procedure, the incidence of GERD is expectedly higher in POEM.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed., Pg 1124.

questions.text: All of these are premalignant conditions for Carcinoma Esophagus except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schatzki ring

 

Explanation

 

Corrosive injury and Achalasia increase the risk of squamous cell CA, while Barrett’s increases the risk of adenocarcinoma of the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schatzki ring is not considered a premalignant condition for carcinoma of the esophagus, whereas corrosive injury, achalasia cardia, and Barrett’s esophagus are known to be associated with an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1136.

choices.text: Progressive dysphagia
Weight loss

questions.text: A 65-year-old smoker male is found to have a mass in lower esophagus. What is the most common symptom of Carcinoma esophagus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Progressive dysphagia

 

Option C:

 

  • “Progressive dysphagia” is the most common symptom, related to increasing luminal obstruction by cancer. Early symptoms may include a mild hold-up sensation that, if ignored, will progress from dysphagia to a solid, soft and eventually to a liquid diet. There may often be anorexia, weight loss, odynophagia and regurgitation symptoms.
  • Hoarseness may indicate involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve. Aspiration and choking symptoms may be related not only to tumour obstruction but also to the presence of an esophagus–airway fistula.
  • Choking and coughing on drinking water are typical of fistulation and associated hemoptysis is common. Blood loss is less common for squamous cells than adenocarcinoma.

 

Educational objective:

 

“Progressive dysphagia” is the most common symptom of Ca Esophagus.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1136.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is diagnosed with esophageal carcinoma. Radiological investigations show a 2 cm tumor in the lower part of the esophagus without the involvement of mediastinal lymph nodes. On biopsy, it is found to be a squamous cell carcinoma extending up to the submucosa. There is no distant metastasis. What is the best method for management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgery +/- adjuvant chemotherapy

 

Option A: 
 

Surgery alone (with/without chemotherapy) may be indicated for localized esophageal cancer (for instance, T1b, T2, N0) where there is no evidence of lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. Esophagectomy with lymphadenectomy aims to completely remove the tumor and potentially cure the patient.

 

Surgical resection alone (with/without chemotherapy) is generally indicated for more advanced cancers when endoscopic treatment is unlikely to be curative (T1b, T2, N0). For patients with more advanced diseases (≥T3, N+), multimodality treatment is usually preferred.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Chemotherapy followed by surgery. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery may be considered for locally advanced esophageal cancers, often when there is lymph node involvement or a larger primary tumor, to shrink the tumor before surgical resection.

 

Option C: Chemoradiation followed by surgery. Neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy followed by surgery is an option for locally advanced esophageal cancer, particularly for patients with T3 or T4 tumors or those with positive lymph nodes (N+).

 

Option D: Endoscopic resection followed by chemoradiation. Endoscopic resection may be feasible in T1a tumors. Adjuvant chemoradiation (after surgery) may be indicated if there is concern for residual disease after surgery or in cases where preoperative staging underestimates the extent of the disease.

 

Given the described scenario of a 2 cm squamous cell carcinoma confined to the submucosa without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis (T1b, N0, M0), Option A: Surgery +/- chemotherapy is the most appropriate method for management, as per the answer provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with a small (2 cm), localized squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus extending to the submucosa without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis, the recommended management is surgical resection with/without chemotherapy.

 

Surgical resection consists of esophagectomy along with the removal of the involved lymph nodes. Endoscopic mucosal resection can be considered for smaller tumors that are confined to the esophageal mucosa (T1a). For patients who are medically unfit for surgery or have unresectable tumors, chemoradiation can be considered.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Edition pg 1141.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was diagnosed with esophageal carcinoma. Endoscopic ultrasonography showed a 4 cm mass in the middle esophagus above the aortic arch. Which surgical approach will you use?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mckeown’s approach

 

Option A:

 

Mckeown’s approach This triple approach is typically used for tumors in the upper or middle third of the esophagus. It involves abdominal, thoracic, and neck incisions, with the anastomosis usually made in the neck, which provides good exposure for tumors above the aortic arch.

 

The best management of esophageal carcinoma is esophagectomy.

 

Given a 4 cm mass in the middle esophagus above the aortic arch, the Option A: Mckeown’s approach would be the most suitable surgical method due to the location of the tumor.

 

Explanation:

 

When choosing the appropriate surgical approach for esophageal carcinoma, the location of the tumor within the esophagus is a crucial determining factor. Let's evaluate the surgical options based on the tumor's described location:

 

Option B: Ivor Lewis approach The Ivor Lewis, or double approach, is mainly used for tumors in the lower third of the esophagus. This technique involves abdominal and thoracic incisions, with the anastomosis created within the chest.

 

Option C: Orringer’s approach Also known as the transhiatal approach, this is generally utilized for tumors of the lower third or middle half of the esophagus. The anastomosis is made in the neck, but the approach avoids thoracic incisions, which might be beneficial for patients with poor pulmonary reserve.

 

Option D: Trans hiatal approach This approach is same as Orringer’s and is used for lower third esophageal tumors, with the anastomosis also performed in the neck, without thoracotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For esophageal carcinoma located in the middle third of the esophagus, the Mckeown's triple approach is typically the surgical technique of choice, offering optimal exposure for resection and anastomosis.

 

The 3 main approaches are:

 

  1. Mckeown’s (triple) approach:

    • Done for upper 1/3rd and mid 1/3rd tumours

    • Anastomosis site is neck

    • Abdominal, thoracic and left neck incisions made

  2. Transhiatal approach (Orringer’s)

    • Lower 1/3rd tumours

    • Anastomosis site in neck

  3. Ivor Lewis (double) approach:

    • Lower 1/3rd esophageal tumours

    • Anastomosis site in thorax

 

In esophagectomy, a proximal margin of 10cm and distal margin of 5cms are taken.

 

Ref: 28th edition bailey pg 1143

questions.text: Palliative options for esophageal carcinoma include stent placement. What is the most common complication of the procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Migration

 

Option C:

 

Most common complication of placing a stent in the esophagus is stent migration.

 

Palliative options for esophageal carcinoma include:

 

  • Stent placement
  • Feeding jejunostomy/gastrostomy
  • Chemo or Radiotherapy

 

Other complications of stents:

 

  • Odynophagia
  • Tumour ingrowth
  • Chest pain
  • Severe reflux

 

Educational objective:

 

Most common complication of placing a stent in the esophagus for palliation in Ca Esophagus is stent migration.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1146

questions.text: According to the latest 8th edition AJCC guidelines, which parameter will you choose for determining the prognosis of esophageal cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T stage

 

Educational Objective:

 

The T stage, which reflects the depth of tumor invasion, is a crucial parameter in the AJCC staging system for determining the prognosis of esophageal cancer.

 

The T stage advances as the tumour invades from mucosa deep to muscle, adventitia and beyond the esophagus. Careful disease staging is essential to guide therapy.

 

 

Ref: pg 1138, Bailey and Love 28th ed

questions.text: Which of the below is not an indication for performing the test shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Patients with Barrett’s on endoscopy

 

This is a complication of GERD which is managed as per degree of metaplasia/dysplasia. 24 hour pH is not mandatory, as it is diagnosed on biopsy.

 

In patients with atypical (Option C) or persistent symptoms despite PPI therapy (Option D), oesophageal manometry and ambulatory pH recording (with or without impedance measurement) are justified to establish the diagnosis and guide management. 

In patients considered for surgery (Option A), it is also prudent to have objective proof of significant reflux before embarking on a potentially irreversible invasive procedure.

 

Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1114.

choices.text: Barrett's esophagus, Biopsy at GE junction

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with long-standing history of GERD undergoes endoscopic evaluation. He is found to salmon colored tongue-like projections of the mucosa above the GE junction. What is the diagnosis and next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Barrett esophagus, multiple quadrant biopsies

 

Explanation:

Options A and B:

Barrett’s esophagus is characterized by the presence of salmon-colored mucosa in the lower esophagus, due to the abnormal columnar epithelium replacing the normal squamous epithelium, often as a result of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It is diagnosed by multiple 4 quadrant biopsies and 1-2 cm intervals as per Seattle protocol.

 

Option C: GERD, 24 hour pH
GERD alone does not involve salmon-colored mucosa as a feature.

Option D: Schatzki’s ring, biopsy
A Schatzki’s ring is a benign, thin, circumferential constriction in the lower esophagus and does not present with salmon-colored mucosa.

 

The correct answer is Option B: Barrett’s esophagus, with multiple quadrant biopsies which is indeed associated with salmon-colored mucosa in the lower esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett’s esophagus is identified by the appearance of salmon-colored mucosa in the lower esophagus and is a consequence of chronic GERD. Recognition of this endoscopic finding is critical for the diagnosis and management of Barrett’s esophagus, given its potential for progression to esophageal adenocarcinoma.

 

  • Barrett’s esophagus is a known complication of GERD. It is the proximal migration of columnar epithelium (salmon-coloured mucosa) in the lower esophagus extending more than 1 cm above the Gastro-esophageal Junction. The additional criterion of the biopsy-proven presence of mucus-secreting goblet cells or intestinal metaplasia is controversial.

choices.text: Dysphagia is due to the presence of a post-cricoid web.
Myotomy is done to dilate the webs.
Correcting the Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) may improve dysphagia and pain

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with dysphagia and generalized weakness for 3 months. Peripheral blood smear revealed hypochromic, microcytic anemia. A contrast imaging was done which revealed the following clinical picture. What about the following condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myotomy is done to dilate the webs

 

Option B:

 

Myotomy is done to dilate the webs


False. Myotomy, a surgical incision into a muscle, is not the method used to dilate esophageal webs. Instead, dilation is typically performed with esophageal bougies or dilators.

 

The above barium study is suggestive of Plummer Vinson syndrome.

 

Esophageal bougies are used to dilate the post cricoid webs in Plummer Vinson syndrome/ Patterson Kelly syndrome.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Dysphagia is due to the presence of a post-cricoid web. True. Dysphagia in Plummer Vinson syndrome is typically due to the presence of an esophageal web, often located post-cricoidally.

 

Option C: Correcting the IDA may improve dysphagia and pain. True. Correcting iron deficiency anemia (IDA) can lead to an improvement in dysphagia and pain in patients with Plummer Vinson syndrome.

 

Option D: It’s a pre malignant condition. True. Plummer Vinson syndrome is associated with an increased risk of hypopharyngeal and upper esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct management of esophageal webs in Plummer Vinson syndrome involves dilation with bougies or dilators, not myotomy. Addressing underlying iron deficiency anemia can also improve symptoms.

 

It is also called sideropenic dysphagia.

 

It denotes the presence of a post-cricoid web that is associated with the following:

 

  • Iron-deficiency anemia

  • Glossitis

  • Koilonychia

  • Some patients may have oropharyngeal leukoplakia, and this may account for an alleged increased risk of developing hypopharyngeal cancer.

 

Ref: Bailey and love 27th ed: pg 1105

choices.text: Los Angeles - Severity of GERD on endoscopy
Eckhardt - Severity of GERD based on symptoms
Chicago - Types of Achalasia based on manometry
Prague - Diagnosis of Barrett’s

questions.text: Identify the mismatch classification and score from below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Eckhardt - Severity of GERD based on symptoms.

 

Option B:

 

Eckhardt score is for severity of Achalasia, and utilizes the symptoms of dysphagia, regurgitation, weight loss and heart burn.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Los Angeles - Severity of GERD on endoscopy: This refers to the Los Angeles Classification System, which grades the severity of esophagitis based on endoscopic findings, such as the presence and extent of erosions or ulcerations in the esophagus. It's a suitable match.

 

Option C. Chicago - Types of Achalasia based on manometry: The Chicago Classification System is used to categorize esophageal motility disorders, including achalasia, based on findings from esophageal manometry. This system identifies different types of achalasia and other motility disorders based on characteristic patterns of esophageal muscle dysfunction. This option is also a suitable match.

 

Option D. Prague - Diagnosis of Barrett's: The Prague C & M Criteria are used to standardize the endoscopic evaluation and reporting of Barrett's esophagus. These criteria involve assessing the length and circumferential extent of the Barrett's segment.

 

Educational objective:

 

Los Angeles classification - Severity of GERD on endoscopy

 

Chicago classification - Types of Achalasia based on manometry.

 

Prague classification - Diagnosis of Barrett's

 

Eckhardt score - severity of Achalasia

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1122.

choices.text: Best seen on upper GI endoscopy
Mixed type involves upward migration of GE junction
Rolling type is commonly linked to GERD
Surgical management is rarely required

questions.text: Which of these is correct about hiatus hernia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mixed type involves upward migration of GE junction

 

Option B.

 

Mixed type involves upward migration of GE junction: This statement is accurate. In a mixed hiatus hernia, both the stomach and the gastroesophageal (GE) junction can herniate through the esophageal hiatus, with the GE junction migrating above the diaphragm. This type of hernia is characterized by both sliding and paraesophageal components.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Best seen on upper GI endoscopy: This statement is incorrect. Hiatus hernias, especially smaller ones, may be missed during upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy. CT with oral contrast is the preferred modality for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Rolling type is commonly linked to GERD: This statement is incorrect. A rolling (or paraesophageal) hiatus hernia involves the stomach herniating through the esophageal hiatus alongside the GE junction, typically resulting in a "rolled" appearance of the gastric fundus. This typically presents with obstructive symptoms.

 

Option D. Surgical management is rarely required: This statement is generally incorrect. While smaller hiatus hernias may not always require surgical intervention, larger or symptomatic hernias often necessitate surgical repair, especially if they cause significant symptoms like reflux, chest pain, or difficulty swallowing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both sliding (type 1) and mixed (type 3) hiatus hernias are associated with migration of GE junction. CT with contrast is diagnostic, and surgery is required for larger or symptomatic hiatus hernias.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1117-1118.

choices.text: Proximal esophagus shows ineffective peristalsis
Heller’s myotomy is ideal for all types of achalasia
Epiphrenic diverticula are associated with achalasia
Weight loss is included in triad of achalasia

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about achalasia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heller’s myotomy is ideal for all types of achalasia

 

Option B.

 

Heller’s myotomy is ideal for all types of achalasia: This statement is incorrect. While Heller's myotomy, a surgical procedure that involves cutting the muscles at the lower esophageal sphincter, is a primary treatment for achalasia, it may not be suitable for all types. In some cases, particularly those with a type III achalasia or spastic variants, POEM with long myotomy is more effective.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Proximal esophagus shows ineffective peristalsis: This statement is correct. In achalasia, the primary motor abnormality is the loss of esophageal peristalsis, particularly in the lower esophagus. Instead of the coordinated contractions that propel food downward, there is a lack of effective peristalsis, leading to impaired esophageal emptying.

 

Option C. Epiphrenic diverticula are associated with achalasia: This statement is correct. Epiphrenic diverticula, which are outpouchings of the esophageal wall located in the lower part of the esophagus, are often associated with achalasia. These diverticula develop due to increased pressure in the distal esophagus resulting from the impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter characteristic of achalasia.

 

Option D. Weight loss is included in the triad of achalasia. It includes dysphagia and regurgitation as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia is a motility disorder characterised by tight lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and ineffective peristalsis. Heller’s myotomy is the preferred treatment, except in type 3 achalasia where POEM is preferred.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1121-24.
